If you're fired up to help, the Blue Button team at the VA needs a product manager to grow their API work: https://t.co/Vvbfhw8EZk
Blue Button really did spring from a single working group meeting @MarkleFdn. It was like we were members of a sleeper cell at the moment of activation, with the common goal of patient engagement.
Blue Button is a spigot stuck into the side of the Hoover Dam of health data. And patients get to direct where the data flows.
If you have never understood what Blue Button is - or why people care about it - this post is for you: https://t.co/S75ePq16Qi

"I had recently received information about my health regarding a personal condition. I was scared, and I researched online to find others with this condition." – 22-year-old female. @Hopelab @WellBeingTrust survey

"I found a very good friend in another country that had the same condition as I did, and it was truly inspiring to have the freedom to tell them about it and likewise them to me!" – 21-year-old male. @Hopelab @WellBeingTrust survey
"I have type 1 diabetes and tried to find a group of teenager type 1’s on Facebook. I did. It was cool. Made some friends." – 14-year-old male. @Hopelab @WellBeingTrust survey
We asked people to give us an example of a time they went online to try to find other people with health concerns similar to theirs. What was the situation? How did it turn out?

Half (51%) of young adults in the U.S. say they have tried to find people online with health concerns similar to their own, compared to 25% of teens - @Hopelab @WellBeingTrust survey #PeerHealthAdvice
81% of LGBTQ people ages 14-22 say they have read or watched other people share about their health experiences online, compared to 57% of cisgender/straight youth - @Hopelab @WellBeingTrust survey

Seven in ten young adults (18-22 year-olds) say they have read or watched other people share about their health experiences online, compared to half of teens (14-17 year-olds) - @Hopelab @WellBeingTrust survey
Six in ten young people in the U.S. say they have read or watched other people share about their health experiences online - @Hopelab @WellBeingTrust survey

One in three young people in the U.S. say they have found health peers online and, of those, 91% say their last experience with an online peer was helpful - @Hopelab @WellBeingTrust survey https://t.co/wgfQAofmcg

But prize competitions historically enshrined the existing hierarchy - in England the primary predictor of winning was being an alum of Oxford or Cambridge. Only recently have prizes come back into vogue in the U.S.
Alexander Hamilton and Ben Franklin loved prize competitions and wanted to make them a big part of the American experiment - Zorina Khan, speaking at @SI_Invention
